newsitem.title: DUBAI: UAE has 96 budget surplus after projected deficit.
newsitem.headline: UAE has 96 budget surplus after projected deficit.

text.p: Higher oil prices helped the United Arab Emirates post a surplus of 3.559 billion dirhams ($969 million) on its federal budget in 1996 after a deficit of 938.7 million dirhams a year earlier, provisional figures show.

The latest Central Bank report on Monday showed federal revenues of 20.581 billion dirhams and expenditure of 17.022 billion at end-1996, compared to 1995 income of 16.894 billion dirhams and spending of 17.833 billion.
At the beginning of 1996 the UAE had projected a deficit of 858 million dirhams for the year. It had forecast 1996 spending at 18.25 billion and revenue at 17.40 billion.
But as oil prices rose during 1996, some economists had expected the deficit to be lower, or even wiped out.
Preliminary Central Bank data show that crude oil at factor cost contributed 57 billion dirhams at current prices to gross domestic product in 1996 from an estimated 47.24 billion in 1995.

Bankers estimate that the federal budget represents only about a third of consolidated government spending of the seven emirates, but it is nevertheless important as a barometer. ($1=3.67 dirhams) ($ = 3.672 UAE Dirhams)
